hook.text: A trolley is heading toward five people. You can divert it to kill one. What do you do ‚Äî and why?

buildup.text: Moral reasoning applies logic to ethical questions. Different frameworks give different answers.

discovery.text: Utilitarians save five. Deontologists refuse to use someone as a means. Virtue ethicists ask what a good person does.

twist.text: Most moral decisions aren't trolley problems. They're messy, ambiguous, and made under time pressure.

climax.text: Good moral reasoning doesn't give you one right answer. It gives you better tools for navigating hard ones.

punchline.text: Ethics isn't about easy answers. It's about better questions.

quiz.question: Why do different ethical frameworks give different answers to the trolley problem?
options: One is right and the others are wrong
